data.title: Christian Carl Frederik Albert Alexander Vilhelm (Vilhelm) Konge af Danmark (1870-1947)

data.meta_description: Is this your ancestor? Compare DNA and explore genealogy for Christian X (Vilhelm) Konge af Danmark born 1870 Charlottenlund Slot, Charlottenlund, Danmark died 1947 Amalienborg Slot, København, Danmark including ancestors + descendants + 1 photos + 2 genealogist comments + questions + Y-chromosome DNA + more in the free family tree community.
data.text:
Ancestors Descendants

Profile last modified 25 Jan 2024 | Created 10 Aug 2015

This page has been accessed 2,385 times.

Biography

His personal motto was: "Min Gud, mit Land, min Ære" which translates to My God, my Country, my Honor[1][2]

Christian was born 26 September 1870 at Charlottenlund Castle, Gentofte, in Copenhagen, Denmark, the son of Frederik VIII Schleswig-Holstein-Sonderburg-Glücksburg and Louise Bernadotte. [3] He was confirmed on 17 April 1887 in Copenhagen.[4]

He was married to Alexandrine Augusta von Mecklenburg-Schwerin-Oldenburg 26 April 1898 in Cannes, France. They were the parents of two children, Princes Frederik and Knud.[5]

He died 20 April 1947 at Amalienborg Palace in Copenhagen at the age of 76. His remains were buried at Roskilde, Roskilde Municipality, Zealand, Denmark.[6][7]

Obituary:[8]

Death Calls Heroic King of Denmark

Weight of Years and Weak Heart Fatal to Christian

Copenhagen, April 21, (AP)--King Christian X, who ruled his Danish subjects for 35 years and was acclaimed a hero for remaining with the during five bitter wartime years of German occupation, died Sunday of a heart ailment after a 15-day illness. He was 76 years old.

Christian automatically was succeeded on the throne by his 48-year-old son, Crown Prince Frederik, who became King Frederik IX. Under the Danish constitution, Frederik did not have to await a monarchial oath or a formal coronation ceremony before beginning his reign.

Christian died at 11: 04 p.m., eight hours after he lapsed into a coma and his strength began ebbing away. Before he became unconscious, Christian whispered a last farewell to Queen Alexandrine, the crown prince, and his other son, the 47-year-old Prince Knud. [...]

The towering six-foot seven-inch Christian was born at Charlottenborg, September 26, 1870, and succeeded his father, King Frederick VIII, on the throne May 12, 1912.

After the Germans invaded Denmark April 9, 1940, they interfered little with Christian's acvitities at first, apparently seeking to win his cooperation. The always silent often scornful treatment accorded them by the Danes apparently wore on the Nazis' nerves, however, and Christian was interned in Sorgeneri castle in 1943.

He declared then he was a "happy man now," not only because eh was a German prisoner, but also because "I am the chief of a large underground army."

Loved and respected by his subjects almost from the first days of his reign he became adored by them for refusing to flee to a safer country in the face of German occupation threats.
